messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Knowledge Informed Machine Learning using a Weibull-based Loss Function

Paper Abstract: Abstract Machine learning can be enhanced through the integration of external knowledge. This method, called knowledge informed machine learning, is also applicable within the field of Prognostics and Health Management (PHM). In this paper, the various methods of knowledge informed machine learning, from a PHM context, are reviewed with the goal of helping the reader understand the domain. In addition, a knowledge informed machine learning technique is demonstrated, using the common IMS and PRONOSTIA bearing data sets, for remaining useful life (RUL) prediction. Specifically, knowledge is garnered from the field of reliability engineering which is represented through the Weibull distribution. The knowledge is then integrated into a neural network through a novel Weibull-based loss function. A thorough statistical analysis of the Weibull-based loss function is conducted, demonstrating the effectiveness of the method on the PRONOSTIA data set. However, the Weibull-based loss function is less effective on the IMS data set. The results, shortcomings, and benefits of the approach are discussed in length. Finally, all the code is publicly available for the benefit of other researchers.111https://github.com/tvhahn/weibull-knowledge-informed-ml

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Incorporating prior domain knowledge into deep neural networks",
        "Informed machine learning–a taxonomy and survey of integrating knowledge into learning systems",
        "Bearing data set",
        "Pronostia: An experimental platform for bearings accelerated degradation tests",
        "System health monitoring and prognostics—a review of current paradigms and practices",
        "Failure prognosis and applications—a survey of recent literature",
        "Prognostics and health management design for rotary machinery systems—reviews, methodology and applications",
        "Prognostic modelling options for remaining useful life estimation by industry",
        "Machinery health prognostics: A systematic review from data acquisition to rul prediction",
        "Critical wind turbine components prognostics: A comprehensive review",
        "Physics guided neural network for machining tool wear prediction",
        "Wind turbine main bearing fatigue life estimation with physics-informed neural networks",
        "Simulation-driven machine learning: Bearing fault classification",
        "Physics-informed machine learning for dram error modeling",
        "Adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system in modelling fatigue life of multidirectional composite laminates",
        "Optimal maintenance decisions under imperfect inspection",
        "Applications of object-oriented bayesian networks for condition monitoring, root cause analysis and decision support on operation of complex continuous processes",
        "Active learning for accurate analysis of streaming partial discharge data",
        "Reliability engineering, volume 86",
        "Evaluation criteria for reliability-centered maintenance (rcm) processes",
        "Application of Reliability Centred Maintenance to Optimize Operation and Maintenance in Nuclear Power Plants",
        "Real-time fault detection and prognostics for aircraft actuation systems",
        "An intelligent diagnostic/prognostic framework for automotive electrical systems",
        "A hybrid framework combining data-driven and model-based methods for system remaining useful life prediction",
        "Active learning literature survey",
        "A Chat with Andrew on MLOps: From Model-centric to Data-centric AI",
        "Prognosis of machine health condition using neuro-fuzzy systems",
        "Bearing fault prognosis based on health state probability estimation",
        "A statistical distribution function of wide applicability",
        "Wtte-rnn: Weibull time to event recurrent neural network",
        "Reliability analysis for wind turbines with incomplete failure data collected from after the date of initial installation",
        "Prognostics, a new look at statistical life prediction for condition-based maintenance",
        "Plant machinery working life prediction method utilizing reliability and condition-monitoring data",
        "The New Weibull handbook: reliability and statistical analysis for predicting life, safety, supportability, risk, cost and warranty claims",
        "Methodologies for cross-domain data fusion: An overview",
        "Physics-embedded machine learning: case study with electrochemical micro-machining",
        "System-level prognostics and health management: A graph convolutional network–based framework",
        "Learning internal representations by error propagation",
        "Label-free supervision of neural networks with physics and domain knowledge",
        "Analysis of the rolling element bearing data set of the center for intelligent maintenance systems of the university of cincinnati",
        "Accurate bearing remaining useful life prediction based on weibull distribution and artificial neural network",
        "Random search for hyper-parameter optimization",
        "Adam: A method for stochastic optimization",
        "Maximizing Machinery Uptime",
        "Damage mechanics approach for bearing lifetime prognostics",
        "Rolling bearings — Dynamic load ratings and rating life",
        "Recent advancement of deep learning applications to machine condition monitoring part 1: A critical review"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Knowledge Informed Machine Learning using a Weibull-based Loss Function, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
